titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. At the Office Mr Bourne, called and told me he had obtained the Commission of a Captain of Marines, and thanked me, for my solicitation in his favour— Mr Herbert of Alexandria called with a Bill at sixty days sight which I accepted, for a Hogshead of Wine from J. H. March at Madeira— I called at the President’s and proposed that Mr Middleton should be instructed to communicate to the Russian Government a copy of the Convention offered to Great-Britain for the regulation of Neutral and Belligerent rights, and to ascertain if Russia would be willing to accede to it. The President consented— I had begun the draft of an Instruction to Mr Middleton concerning it— I asked the President, if he proposed to send a Minister to France in place of Mr Gallatin. He had not determined; nor has Mr Gallatin been explicit in declining to return to France— He cannot return this year, and he is willing that an appointment should be made to supply his place; if it is thought that the public service so requires— The President asked me what I would advise him to do— I thought the appointment might be postponed; perhaps until Winter; but not over that Season— I observed that the Act of Congress of 3. March 1815. offering the abolition of discriminating duties, and all the Acts founded upon it were so limited that they would expire during the next Session of Congress— A revision of the whole system would be necessary; and I would suggest to him the expediency of considering what notice it will be proper for him to take of it, in the Message at the Commencement of the next Session— He said that he had already in former Messages recommended perseverance in the system, and had seen no reason for changing his opinion— I said that before the opening of the Session, we must have some answer from England, respecting the proposed Negotiations, and perhaps they might render it proper that he should also mention them in the Message— Particularly the project for regulating the principles of Belligerent and Neutral rights in time of War— He said he would consider of this— I mentioned to him that I had heard the Secretary of the Navy had finally consented to accept the vacant Seat on the Bench of the Supreme Court; which he said was true— But he would remain some time longer in the Navy Department; and he added he had not yet thought of whom he should nominate for Mr. Thompson’s successor— The public Newspapers say it has been offered to Mr Southard, the Senator from New-Jersey.

2. V:15. Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack, an hour and a quarter— The tide was going out rapidly, for which reason I began by ascending the river, swimming against the current, and returning with it. We came back in the quarter of an hour the space which it had taken us the full hour to traverse outwards.— Judge Thruston called at my house in a temper of mind much tranquilised since the day before yesterday— But as his desire to make an excursion continues, I accommodated him with what he had requested— The President was suddenly seized this morning with cramps or convulsions of such extreme violence, that he was at one time believed to be dying; and he lay upwards of two hours in a state of insensibility. I did not hear of it till the fit was over. I called at his house, and saw there Dr Washington and Mr Hay.— The Dr said the President was deposed to Sleep, and it would be best that no person should see him. Mr Hay said Dr Sim had pronounced the danger to be past, and did not apprehend a renewal of the attack— But Hay added he thought it would be sometime, before it would be prudent to lay before him business of any kind— Before returning home to dinner, I sent to enquire how he was,
and the answer to the Messenger was, much better. In the Evening I went to the theatre and saw the Cure for the Heart-Ache; not so well performed as it was last Summer— The House was very thin— Only two Ladies in the lower boxes; one of whom Mrs Weightman went away immediately after the curtain dropped. When Wemyss came out to announce the next Play, he looked round and said “Lady and Gentlemen— On Tuesday next” &c— I came away also without waiting to see the farce— There was a heavy thunder shower in the middle of the day, and the Evening weather was lowering.

3. V:30. Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack, an hour and a half; first up river and returning with the tide— Heard Mr Little in the morning, from 1. Corinthians 1:23.24. “But we preach Christ crucified, unto the Jews a stumbling block, and unto the Greeks foolishness;—But unto them which are called, both Jews and Greeks, Christ the power of God, and the wisdom of God”— As this is a very common Trinitarian text, Mr Little commented upon it, in the spirit of his own doctrines, without impression upon my mind. After Noon Mrs Adams went with me to the Presbyterian Church, where we heard a stranger, from Mark. 8.36. “For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own Soul.” A grave discourse not very emphatically urged— Ardent doctrines coldly recommended. In the Evening I heard Mr Little again from Luke 21.24. “And they shall fall by the edge of the sword, and shall be led away captive into all Nations: and Jerusalem shall be trodden down of the Gentiles, until the times of the Gentiles be fulfilled.” I was much gratified with this eloquent Sermon upon the dispersion of the Jews and the destruction of Jerusalem, as thus distinctly prophesied by Christ— I finished this day the Draft of a Letter of Instruction to H. Middleton, to go with a copy of the project of a Convention for the regulation of Belligerent and Neutral Rights.

4. V:15. Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack, an hour and ten-minutes—upwards to about the middle of the Tyber Creek, and returned. Mr Myers of Pensacola called at my house. He has been about two Months from that place, and applies for an allowance of a charge by him, as Counsel for Captain Jackson of the Revenue Cutter Louisiana, against the vessel and crew taken by him into Pensacola as Pirates, but discharged. One of the cases upon which the late Spanish Minister Anduaga made violent complaints— Myers was employed by Captain Jackson, there being then no District Attorney at Pensacola. I doubted whether there was any public fund from which Mr Myers’s charge could be paid, but promised to enquire. Mr. Little called upon the subject of the supplementary Commercial Digest, the compilation of which I had determined to commit to him, if he would take upon him the charge of making up those parts of them, which are in foreign languages—French, Spanish and German. He said he understood enough of French for the work himself, and had a friend well versed in the Spanish, and also in commercial affairs who would enable him to do the remainder— I promised to send him the Papers— At the Office, Mr Nourse the Register, brought me an extract of a Letter from Robert Lenox, enclosing copy of one to him, from Sir Simon H. Clarke at London, the object of which was to obtain a Letter of Introduction for Sir Simon H. Clark, to
Mr Rush— Sir Simon has large possessions in the Island of Jamaica. Thinks he has influence with the British Government, and wishes to be useful to the intercourse between the two Countries— I wrote the Letter— Commodore Rodgers, came to ask again my recommendation of W. C. Holmes, to the Secretary of the Navy, for a Midshipman’s warrant— Mr Crafts had written to me to the same effect— I wrote to Mr Thompson— I called at the President’s, and heard that he was convalescent, but not yet able to attend to business, nor to see company. I desired to be informed whenever he should see any person— Captain Thomas Randall came in upon me quite unexpectedly— The Brig Enterprize in which he went to Porto-Rico, and Porto Cavello, was wrecked, coming out of the latter of those places, so that Randall was not able to proceed to the Havanna, but was obliged to come back. The most important part of his Agency has thus been defeated. He gave me some account of his proceedings, and will make a written Report— There was a heavy thunder shower, about the middle of the day; but it cleared up at eve, and I had a short walk with Mrs Adams— My Son George and Mary Hellen went with Mrs Frye to spend some days at Bladensburg.

5. V: Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack one hour and fifty minutes; entirely crossing the Tiber, and touching ground at General Van Ness’s wharf— I still find manifest benefit from this exercise to my health, particularly in bracing the Stomach and the Nerves at this sultry Season. But I am yet to guard against excess and danger— Dr Thornton called on me this Morning; concerning a boy employed in the Patent Office as a Messenger—Robert Fenwick; whom he seems disposed to dismiss— I had afterwards a Letter from the boy himself— George Johnson called and said he was now ready to proceed with the business of the Mills— I gave him the Letter from General Mason, as President of the Bank of Columbia, containing their relinquishment of claim; the like to which I thought necessary in the present case— He wrote me in the Evening that General Mason thought it would be best to do it by a Vote of the Board of Directors, which would be recorded on their Books— Their next Meeting will be on Thursday. There was a heavy Thunder Shower; and the rain returned at intervals from shortly after noon till near Midnight— Mrs Thornton and Mrs Myers were here in the Evening.

6. V. I had taken the fancy to swim across the Potowmack, but doubting whether the thickness of the grass in several places, would not prove an insuperable impediment, I took this morning a small canoe, and was paddled over the river by Antoine— There are three channels of deep water, and three shallow passages where the grass now rises to the very surface and through which it would be scarcely if at all possible to make way by swimming. I was glad I had not attempted it— We bathed on the other side of the river, and swam only a few minutes. I found also that I could not get from the water into the Canoe, without assistance, nor without danger of taking hurt— We landed in returning, at General Van Ness’s Garden; and were out nearly three hours— T. Cook was here; returned from a fortnights visit to Frederick and G. Johnson, who is to see to the Execution and delivery of the Deeds to-morrow— General Macomb just returned from the examination of the Cadets at West-Point, and General Jessup from a Western tour— Macomb says that the School at West-Point is in a state of excellent discipline: the Cadets there being 250 in number; and their improvement in mathematical studies extraordinary. He was accompanied thither from New-York, by Mr Canning, who he says was much pleased with it— At the Office, I was without interruption, and not fully
occupied— Mrs Adams went to Bladensburg, and George came back with her. Mr Frye was here this Evening. Yesterday was fourteen years since I embarked from Charlestown for Russia; and this day six years have passed since I landed at New-York, on my return from Europe— They were both important days in my life— Each the commencement of a Career of high responsibility and momentous trust— The first was signalized by important events, and in its progress and termination were prosperous beyond all that I should have dared to ask— The second is yet unfinished— It has been and is checkered as all the Scenes of human life must be with good and evil, but in the main eminently cheering— Let my heart be grateful for the past, and prepared with resignation and resource for the future.

7. V: Swam in the Potowmack with Antoine. We took the Canoe and started from the rock where I usually undress, I swimming and he following in the Canoe— I took the direction to the Bridge, so as to traverse about half the river, but before reaching the Bridge, I found the grass so thick, and so entangling to my legs and arms, that I could not make my way through them, and was obliged to hold by the Canoe, while he paddled to the Bridge— I there went into the Canoe, we passed to the other side of the Bridge, passed through the place where the grass was so high and thick; then recrossed under the Bridge— I plunged from the Canoe into the River, and swam back, to my undressing Rock. We had been gone one hour and ten minutes from it. I convinced myself thoroughly that the attempt to swim across the river is rendered very dangerous by the grass flats, for although it grows up to the very surface of the Water the depth was every where over my head. I expected George Johnson and Mr Dunlop, to finish the business of the Mills; but there are yet delays from the Bank of Columbia. G. Johnson came to the Office, and shewed me an advertisement that he had prepared for purchasing wheat, and to which I proposed some modification— Captain Randall called, and is going to-morrow to Annapolis— Visit from Mr James Greenleaf of Philadelphia— Evening with Mrs. Adams and George at the Theatre— Tom and Jerry with the Prelude of the Manager in distress a Burlett pleasant, but vulgar— Johnson Hellen came in this Evening from Rockville.

8. V: Swam with Antoine in the Potowmack, to the Bridge against the tide; but the principal difficulty was with the grass. In returning we swam part of the way close to the Bridge—where it is less troublesome— We were an hour and a quarter swimming— George Johnson, and General Mason were at my House upon the Affair of the Mills— The Bank of Columbia did not succeed in their Negotiation with the Bank of the United States, for a new credit of twenty thousand Dollars, and now General Mason proposed a new plan to me, which I also declined— I likewise closed a transaction with Robert Easter; and transferred to him 3000 dollars of Stock in the Bank of the Metropolis, at par, payable in two, three and four years; with annual interest for which I take as mortgage of a lot, and house that he is building upon it, in the Pennsylvania avenue— Mr Calhoun called with Mr Ezra Styles Ely, a Clergyman of Philadelphia, who came to solicit the interposition of the Government in behalf of two of his brothers in prison at Paris— I had received yesterday a Letter and sundry documents from him concerning this affair— I told him I would do what I could for his brothers, but that it
could not be much. At the Office the Baron de Tuyll came with a Newspaper, containing the account of the dinner, given to Captain Hull at Boston, upon his appointment to go and take the place of Stewart, as Commander of the Squadron in the Pacific. He was alarmed at the toasts which smacked strongly of Resistance to the Russian Imperial Ukaze, and was afraid that Instructions might be given to Hull, which might lead to actual collisions with the Russian Naval force in that Sea— He expressed himself in the most conciliatory manner, and with an earnest hope, that as the subject was in amicable negotiation with the fairest hope of a satisfactory arrangement, nothing might occur to increase the difficulties of the case— I told him I would report his observations, and had no doubt the President would direct that Instructions should be given to Captain Hull, to avoid all premature collisions— This would be done in full confidence of the Emperor’s sincere disposition to arrange the affair amicably; and I should candidly assure him, that apart from this consideration, and if the case had been left on the footing of Mr Poletica’s last Letter to me, on this subject Captain Hull’s Instructions undoubtedly would have been to protect the Citizens of the United States in the prosecution of their lawful Commerce— The Baron asked me also to explain to him the meaning of a paragraph, in the Circular from the Secretary of the Treasury to the Collectors of the Customs, on the admission of foreign prizes into our Ports— I gave him the desired explanation— I called at the President’s— He is convalescent— I left several papers with him, and told him of my Conversation this morning with Baron Tuyll— Eve at Home. Fahrenheit 95.

9. IV: Swam in the Potowmack, to the Bridge against the tide, and returned with it— One hour and fifty minutes in the Water; Antoine being still at hand with the Canoe— I was about an hour and a half in going, and not more than twenty minutes returning. Mr Miller, of Virginia who wants employment in the Department of State came with a recommendation from Mr Garnett— But I have no employment to give. Mr George Johnson came, but Mr Dunlop has not yet obtained the necessary papers for the conveyance of the Mills, from General Mason— So that this affair is yet suspended— At the Office Mr Nourse the Register of the Treasury came for the Letter of Introduction for Sir Simon H. Clark to Mr Rush; and will call again on Monday— At the President’s— He received me in his bed chamber, which he was advised not to leave this day— He recommended to me to strike out from the Instruction to Mr Middleton, upon the neutral and belligerent right project, all the reference to the Holy Alliance: because that Treaty being considered in this Country as a mere hypocritical fraud, any reference to it whatever, would have a turn given to it of odious misconstruction here, against myself— I said my reference to the Holy Alliance was merely an Argumentum ad Hominem. It was a call upon the Emperor of Russia, for an Act unequivocally corresponding with the Sentiment that he had proclaimed— A direct appeal to his Conscience to support by Deeds his Professions, and I had been so far from expressing approbation of his Acts, or those of the Holy Alliance, that I had distinctly alluded to them as liable to censure and warned him of the danger to him that the judgment of posterity would contrast them with his Declaration in the Treaty— The President said he had remarked this guard, but still thought it would be best to omit the reference to the
Holy Alliance altogether— I accordingly struck it out, and thereby gave up, what I considered the main Spring of the argument to the Emperor— I relied upon its operation, incomparably more than upon anything else— The President is often afraid of the skittishness of mere popular prejudices, and I am always disposed to brave them— I have much more confidence in the calm and deliberate judgment of the People than he has— I have no doubt that the Newspaper Scavengers, and Scape gibbets, whose republicanism runs in filthy streams from the Press, would have attempted to exhibit this reference to the Holy Alliance in a false and odious point of view, but I would have trusted to the good sense of the people to see through their sophistry and their motives— They would have seen in it what was intended—A powerful engine of persuasion; applied to the heart of him whom it was all important to persuade—A bold and direct address to his intimate conscience; and a warming voice to check and controul his acts bearing hard upon the Liberties of Nations.— In this case as in all others for which Mr Monroe as the Head of his Administration is responsible, I submit my own judgment to his— The only case in which I insisted upon my own, was in the controvery with Jonathan Russell—because in that all the responsability rested upon me— But I have now less Confidence of succeeding with the Emperor— The President was also apprehensive of speaking too favourably of the proposal by France to exempt private property from capture by Sea; least it should appear to countenance her invasion of Spain itself. He advised an additional paragraph to guard against that; which I accordingly wrote— I attended a Meeting of the Trustees of the second Presbyterian Church— The object was to borrow 1200 dollars of the U.S. Branch Bank, to pay the Carpenter— A vote to that effect was taken— Mary Hellen, returned with Mrs Frye from Bladensburg; and Johnson Hellen left us this morning for Rockville. I went this Evening, with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George to the Theatre. Saw Virginius, and the Village Lawyer— Cooper was excellent— The farce laughable.

10. VI: Swam with Antoine to and from the Bridge in one hour and twenty-five minutes. The tide low, and rapidly rising— Heard this Morning at Mr Little’s a Mr Sullivan, from 1. Samuel 16.7 “for the Lord seeth not as man seeth; for man looketh on the outward appearance, but the Lord looketh on the heart.”— Afternoon, with Mrs Adams, heard Mr Baker, from 1. Peter 3.8–9. “Finally, be ye all of one mind, having compassion one of another; love as brethren, be pitiful, be courteous:—Not rendering evil for evil, or railing for railing: but contrariwise blessing”— In the Evening I heard again Mr Sullivan from 2. Corinthians 5.10. “For we must all appear before the judgment Seat of Christ; that every one may receive the things done in his body, according to that he hath done, whether it be good or bad.”— These three texts taken from the different parts of the Scriptures, afford excellent examples of the admirable morality of the Bible. And in spite of all the depravity of the human heart, such precepts must be followed by good fruits. In the intervals between the Morning and afternoon service, I read the newspapers and Letters which came by the Mail— The Letters this day were few.

11. V: Swam with Antoine, to and from the Bridge— One hour and five Minutes only in the water— The tide was strong; with a brisk South-west wind, to stem both of which beyond the Bridge, I found too hard a task— Mr Dunlop and Mr George Johnson were here, and we finished the transaction of the purchase of the Columbia Mills. I executed the Note to the U.S. Branch Bank, with Mortgage of my dwelling House, and transfer in trust of 9800 dollars U.S. 6 per Cents, and I received the Deeds of James Dunlop and Roger Johnson, and the Letter of relinquishment from J. Mason for the Bank of Columbia. Executed also the Articles of Agreement, between George Johnson and me; and commenced our operations by giving him a Check— D. Brent and Lieutt. Ramsay were here about a claim of Ramsay’s, as bearer of despatches from W. Shaler, six or seven years since— The Auditor and Comptroller agreed to take a paper that he produced as a voucher, and his account was allowed. At the Office, I made a draft of an Answer to the Count de Menou’s Note of 11 July— The Count himself called; and had some conversation with me, concerning the circular from the Secretary of the Treasury to the Collectors of the Customs, with which he was in the main highly gratified— But he asked some questions respecting the paragraph which the Baron de Tuyll had found unintelligible. It seems to make it a question whether in the present War, France recognizes the principle that Free Ships make free-goods— He said this had been distinctly declared in his Note to me; and indeed that she did more; she authorized no capture even of Spanish Merchant vessels— I said I supposed the circular had spoken contingently, because in the French Declaration there was a reservation of a right of resorting to reprizals, if Spain should not reciprocate the exemption of merchant vessels from capture— He said the reservation was not upon any thing which Spain should do, but upon what Neutrals might tolerate— I said it seemed to make no difference, since France was to be herself the judge of what would amount to such toleration— But I added that if the case suggested in the Circular should occur immediately we should give France the benefit of the regulation; which he said was all he desired— He promised to write me concerning it to-morrow— I told him of the proposition we had determined to make to Great-Britain and Russia, for establishing this peace to private property on the Ocean, as a principle of the Law of Nations for the future— I told him I should write concerning it to Mr Sheldon, and observed that he might mention it to his Government if he thought proper. He spoke also of his Note concerning Mr Gallatin, and a Negotiation for Claims, which I told him I should answer in a day or two— I received a Note from Mr Addington mentioning that Mr Canning had sailed from New-York on the 9th. and asking an interview, which I appointed for to-morrow at 2. O’Clock— Evening walk with George.

12. VI. Swam in the Potowmack alone; Antoine having taken a hurt in the ear— I went to the Bridge and returned in an hour— The tide was rising; but so slowly that there was little difference in the time of going or returning— Thunder Showers great part of the day. I went to the Office late and found Mr Addington there. He said he had come to announce his entrance upon his functions, and his personal disposition to promote by all the means in his power the harmony between the two Countries— He spoke of the delay in the arrival of Mr Jackson the Slave indemnity Commissioner, for which he could not account, but did account by conjecture. I told him I would endeavour to answer him on the complaints against Harvey Strong, the Consul at Glasgow; and observed that the delay to answer hitherto had been occasioned by
the real difficulties of the case. He shewed an earnest desire to receive the answer, and some animosity against Strong. I called at the President’s and found him much recovered. Read to him the Drafts of an answer to the Count de Menou’s Note of 11. July, and of an Instruction to A. H. Everett, on the Dutch discriminating duties, both of which he approved. I mentioned to him the remarks of the Baron de Tuyll and the Count de Menou, upon one paragraph in the Circular from the Secretary of the Treasury to the Collectors— The President said he himself had noticed that paragraph—and that perhaps an explanatory Letter might go to the Collectors— That paragraph was indeed totally unnecessary to the circular; it is introduced in the most awkward manner, and when I enquire why it was inserted, the motive which suggests itself is such as I am unwilling to credit— Yet it is altogether in the character of the Man. I was at the Theatre this Evening; with Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George— The Play was Rule a wife, and have a wife— Cooper in the part of Leon— The farce Where shall I dine? Sponge by Wemyss. Home in a Hack— Our Carriage and Horses started yesterday for Frenchtown.

13. VI. Swam alone to and from the Bridge, in 50 minutes— The tide at the lowest—current imperceptible— In returning I passed under the Draw-Bridge— Rain great part of the day. Lieutenant Newell of the Navy, arrived from Thompson’s Island, and brought me a packet from J. S. Wilcocks, Consul at Mexico— Mr Preble was at the Office to enquire if certain vouchers required from Spain for the Commission of Claims under the Florida Treaty had been received; and to offer to go himself as a special messenger to Spain, if it should be found proper to send one. I made a draft of a short Letter to H. Nelson, and finished one to D. Sheldon. Evening visit from Mr Petry; and Mr and Mrs. Frye were here. R. Buchanan remained here.

14. IV:45. At half past five, Mrs. Adams, with my Son George, Mrs Guista, and Robert Buchanan went off in the Stage. Robert Buchanan goes to visit his relations at Baltimore. Mrs. Adams precedes me by a few days, and I hope to find her next week on Friday at New-York, whence we are to proceed to Quincy— George, after having been nearly two years with me, pursuing his Law-Studies, now goes to finish the course previous to his admission to the Bar, in Mr Webster’s Office at Boston— He has good dispositions and virtuous principles. May the blessing from above be with him!— I swam an hour in the river—ascending towards the Tyber creek, against a rapid tide, which I found it very difficult to stem— The mother of John Cunningham, a Marine now with Commodore Porter, at Thompson’s Island came to obtain his discharge— I referred her to the Secretaries of War and of the Navy. Mr Bailey was here. Wishes the appointment of Secretary to the Slave-indemnity Commission. Major Roberdeau to apologize for not having yet finished the copies of the two maps— A Mr Sanford, for a place in the Department of State— Mr G. Johnson with Dunlop’s deed, which is at last complete. Mr Little, about the Supplementary Commercial Digest— Tastet is to be his Spanish Translator— At the Office, Baron de Tuyll came and read to me part of a despatch from Count Lieven of 19. June— The British Government refused to prohibit the sale of Prizes in British Ports— I was at the President’s—read to him a draft of an Instruction to D. Sheldon, which he approved— Appointed a Cabinet Meeting for to-morrow at one. Evening at the Theatre—Damon and Pythias— Cooper as Damon— Is he jealous?—from the French, and a copy of French manners.

15. V:30. Swam alone in the Potowmack an hour and ten minutes; to near the mouth of the Tyber, against the tide. Cabinet Meeting at the President’s at one— Mr Wirt absent, from indisposition— The Subject first mentioned by the President for Consideration was a Letter to me from Andreas Luriottis at London, styling himself Envoy of the provisional Government of the Greeks; a copy of which was sent me some months since by R. Rush— This Letter recommending the cause of the Greeks, solicited of the United States, recognition, Alliance and Assistance— It was proper to give a distinct answer to this Letter, and I had asked the President’s directions what the answer should be— The President now proposed the question— Mr Gallatin had proposed in one of his last despatches, as if he was serious that we should assist the Greeks with our naval force in the Mediterranean—one frigate, one Corvette, and one Schooner. Mr Crawford and Mr Calhoun inclined to countenance this project— Crawford asked hesitatingly whether we were at Peace with Turkey, and seemed only to wait for opposition, to maintain that we were not. Calhoun descanted upon his great enthusiasm for the Cause of the Greeks; he was for taking no heed of Turkey, whatever. In this as in many other cases these Gentlemen have two sources of eloquence at these cabinet Meetings—one with reference to sentiment, and the other to action— Their enthusiasm for the Greeks is all Sentiment, and the Standard of this is the prevailing popular feeling— As for actions they are seldom agreed, and after two hours of discussion this day, the subject was dismissed leaving it precisely where it was— Nothing determined, and nothing practicable proposed by either of them— Seeing their drift, I did not think it necessary to discuss their doubts whether we were at Peace with Turkey— Their contempt for the Sublime Porte, or their enthusiasm for the Cause of the Greeks— I have not much esteem for the enthusiasm which evaporates in words; and I told the President, I thought not quite so lightly of a War with Turkey. I said I would prepare an answer to Mr Luriottis and an Instruction to Mr Rush for his consideration. He had proposed the question whether a secret Agent should be sent to Greece— Calhoun mentioned Edward Everett; and I named Lyman; but we cannot send a secret Agent— Our Agents never will be secret. The President informed us that Mr Thompson, the Secretary of the Navy had consented to accept the vacant Seat upon the Bench of the Supreme Court; and that he had thought of Mr Southard the Senator from New-Jersey, for the Navy Department— But he had not written to Mr Southard, nor given him any notice of his intention, nor was he under any engagement or promise whatever to appoint him— He had thought of him as a man of abilities, a native of the State of New-Jersey, one of the original thirteen, and from which there has never been a member of the Administration. He now mentioned it, because three of us stood in peculiar relations with reference to the succession to the place now occupied by him— He considered it honourable to us all, that large portions of the Country were disposed to support each of us for that station— His own confidence in each of us was entire and unimpaired— He made these remarks, not with the expectation that either of us would reply to them, but in reference to the appointment of a Secretary of the Navy; to say that if either of us had any observations to make he would give them full Consideration— As to the Mission to France, he had wished that Mr Gallatin should return thither; but Mr Gallatin himself had urged him to make another appointment and he had thought of Mr James Brown of Louisiana— He was of opinion that in the present critical state of Europe this appointment should be made without delay— This address of the President, was followed by a pause of Silence, which I terminated, by asking Mr Thompson, when he proposed to quit the Department and enter upon his judicial Office. He intimated, not
very soon, and that he thought it would not be necessary for him to hold the next coming Circuit Courts in New-York, Connecticut and Vermont— The President thought it would be best that he should, and said the Government would be blamed if those terms should pass without a Circuit judge to hold them— Mr Thompson made some question as to the Law, and asked me if I had examined the two Acts of Congress of 1802 and 1808.— By the first the President has the power of allotting a judge to hold the circuit. The second provides that the judge residing in the Circuit shall hold the Circuit Court.— Mr Thompson had some doubts whether his legal residence was in the second District, as he has dwelt for the last four years here. The President said he considered himself as residing in Virginia though he has lived here these twelve years— Mr Calhoun also considered himself as residing in South-Carolina— The President finally asked Mr Thompson to remain with him a few minutes alone— It is remarkable that several newspapers have some days since announced the appointment of Mr Southard to the Navy Department as already made; and some of them have fixed upon the last of this month as the time when he is to enter upon the duties of the office. He is said to be a devoted partizan of Mr Calhoun; which I suppose was the occasion of the President’s remarks on announcing his intention to appoint him— I took a short, solitary Evening walk.

16. VI: There was in the Night one of the most violent thunder-storms, I ever witnessed; which began about one and continued till near four in the morning; with torrents of rain, and flights of Hail, which cracked several squares of window glass, and that of my thermometer. I was up several times in the Night; and had broken rest.— A slight sore throat also since yesterday Morning, caused me to cease my visits to the Potowmack. I walked to the Capitol Hill, and deposited at the Register’s Office, four deeds to be recorded— At the Office I was visited by Mr Ross from Newburgh, where he remembered having seen me in Octr. 1818. He talked New-York Politics now as he did then— He had just been with Mr Crawford, who he says is much exasperated against Coll. Gardiner the Editor of the New-York Patriot; a paper lately established in that City, and which has taken a decided stand against him. A judge Taylor likewise, called to see me; of North Carolina—travelling Northward with his family, for his Lady’s health— And Lieutenant Levy of the Navy; who is going to Europe, to visit Naval Arsenals, and acquire professional information— He asked for Letter of introduction to Consuls, and offered to take despatches— I called at the President’s and read to him my drafts of an answer to Luriottis the Greek Agent, and of an Instruction concerning it to R. Rush; both which he approved— Mr Jackson the British Commissioner under the Slave-indemnity Convention has at length arrived at New-York— But I received a Note from Mr Addington saying that he was detained there by the illness of a Child; and may be expected in a very few days— I consulted the President who thought it would not be absolutely necessary for me to be here at the opening of the Commission. The business might be done by Mr Brent, with the assistance of Mr Hay— I spoke of it to Mr Hay— Evening at the Theatre. Macbeth—(Cooper) and Lovers Quarrels.

17. VI. Heard Mr Little in the morning from Job. 35.5. [“]Look unto the heavens and see; and behold the clouds which are higher than thou. 6. If thou sinnest, what doest thou against him? or if thy transgressions be multiplied, what doest thou unto him? 7. If thou be righteous, what givest thou him? or what receiveth he of thine hand? 8. Thy wickedness may hurt a man as thou art: and thy righteousness may profit the son of man.” This is admirable morality; and was urged as conclusive proof against the doctrine of atonement. That human righteousness or guilt can in no wise affect God; but are to be estimated only by their consequences to our own species. It is indeed inconceivable that the Creator of the world should be affected, by the good or evil of a worm— Virtue or Vice must be altogether included in the relations of Man to Man— I missed the afternoon service at Mr Baker’s, by too much engagedness in reading; but heard Mr Little again in the Evening; from Ephesians 5.17. “Wherefore, be ye not unwise, but understanding what the will of the Lord is.” Received a Letter to Mary, from Mrs. Adams at Wilmington— Suffered still with a sore throat.

18. V: As my departure approaches, business presses upon me. I was engaged early this morning in assorting papers, which had got into confusion. George Johnson was here, and I gave him a check on the Branch Bank to set him fully at work with the Mills— He said he should begin to-morrow— William Brown also came, for employment in the Department of State— The Bank of Columbia, in which he is a Clerk, will dismiss him in a few days as supernumerary. At the Office, came Lieutt. Kirby with Captain Sands interested in an Estate in the Danish Island of St. Croix, subject to the duty of detraction, from which he wishes to obtain its exemption— He had sent a memorial from New-Orleans about it in December 1820 with which nothing had been done— I told him that we had no diplomatic agent in Denmark, but that it was proposed to send a temporary Agent there in the course of a few Months and he should be charged with this business— Lieutenant Levy came and took leave. He is to be the bearer of despatches to our Ministers in Europe; and they are to be sent to him at Philadelphia— Mr Herbert of Alexandria came with a new order for Madeira wine from J. H. March— I took to the President’s a draft of an Answer to Mr Addington, to the complaint made by order of the British Government against Harvey Strong; our Consul at Glasgow, which he approved, suggesting a slight alteration— Mr Thompson, Secretary of the Navy was at the President’s— His Commission as a Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States was this day made out, leaving the date in blank— He took an allotment from the President to hold the Court in the second Circuit according to the Law of 1802— I wrote several short Letters, preparatory to my leaving the City— Evening walk to Mr Frye’s.

19. V:30—Mr George Hay called at my house this Morning— Mr Calhoun with Coll. Haynes of New-York— At the Office, I found Mr Addington, who had a Letter from Mr Jackson, the British Slave indemnity Commissioner, informing him that he expected to arrive here to-morrow with Mr Cheves, who is the Commissioner on the part of the United States— Mr Jackson has been detained at New-York several days by the illness and death of a child. Mr M’Tavish the British arbitrator resides at Baltimore and is expected to-morrow with the two
Commissioners— Baron Tuyll the Russian Minister came to take leave, and Count de Menou the Charge d’Affaires from France, with two French naval Officers, commanders of vessels of War, just arrived at Norfolk from the West-Indies— I received a Letter from Judge Johnson of South-Carolina, enclosing a printed copy of his decision, upon a Habeas Corpus, in the case of a British subject named Elkison, a coloured man, imprisoned under an Act of South-Carolina, which he declares to be unconstitutional— Mr Canning remonstrated against this Act last Winter, and we were assured it should sleep. I sent judge Johnson’s Letter to the President— Received also a Letter enclosing a Bill of Exchange for 30 dollars, drawn by J. Q. A. Boyd, upon me, from Lima— Answered that he had no authority to draw upon me. I was detained at the Office till half-past seven O’Clock. After dinner, judge W. Cranch called at my house. He and Mrs Cranch have been in this City these ten days, nursing their relations Mr and Mrs Elliot, who have been dangerously ill with bilious fevers— I called at the President’s to consult with him upon Judge Johnson’s Letter; but he was already in bed— I betook myself to mine about ten.

20. IV:45. Left Washington on the Stage at six. Among the passengers was Mrs Timberlake, with a small female child, as far as Rossburg, where we breakfasted. She was out there expecting to meet her husband, coming from Baltimore. Mr Dugan, an Officer in one of the Departments, and Cooper the Comedian; who finished last Evening an engagement for five Nights, at the Theatre. We travelled slowly, and arrived after 3. P.M. at Baltimore— Dined there at Barnum’s, with Cooper, and at 5. proceeded in the Steam-boat Constitution; a new and very elegant Boat to Frenchtown, which we reached about Midnight. The day and Evening were oppressively warm; so that in the Birth to which I betook myself I found no rest.

21. We travelled in Stages to Newcastle, where we arrived at four in the morning. Embarked immediately in the Steam-boat Baltimore and arrived at half past nine at Philadelphia— Parted here from Cooper without taking leave as usually happens with Steam boat companions; and went to Judd’s Hotel in South third Street. Met there a Mr Darrel who brought me a Letter from R. M. Harrison, Consul at Antigua. Called at the Bank of the United States, and there saw the President, N. Biddle— Then at S. Ewing’s—who went with me to Mr Hopkinson’s. Saw there Mrs Hopkinson, and one of their Sons— Called with Mr Hopkinson’s on R. Walsh at his Office. I dined at S. Ewing’s, called at Miss Shinn’s and twice at G. Rundle’s— Found him in the Evening, and received a check for dividends on Schuylkill Bridge Stock— Evening at C. J. Ingersoll’s, and at Ewings; and returned to my lodgings about nine— Rain and Cool weather.

22. V:15. At six I took the Steam-Boat Pennsylvania, to Bordentown— Mr Hopkinson went with me— Arrived about eleven— Went for a few minutes to his house; but his daughter Elizabeth was gone out. Took the Stage immediately to Brunswick 28 Miles, which we reached between four and five P.M.—then the Steam-boat Rive-Branch to New-York. General Scott came on board the boat from Staten-Island. About nine in the Evening we landed at New-York, and I came to the City Hotel. Mrs Adams has not returned from Fish-kill landing.

23. VI.Mrs Adams with George and Mrs Giusta came in, before I had risen. Returned from Mr De Wint’s, by the North river Steam-boat. I called at Mr M’Cormick’s, but he was not at home. Then on Charles King at his Office— Then upon Coll. Trumbull’s, where I saw his Picture of the surrender of General Washington’s Commission to Congress; and the engraving of the Declaration of Independence, which is just finished— We had visits from Coll. and Mrs Trumbull, W. Gracie, Mr and Mrs Van Rensselaer (W. Foster’s daughter) Mr and Mrs Colden which
absorbed the Morning. Charles King dined with us— At four in the afternoon we embarked in the Steam-boat Fulton, Captain Comstock, and in a few minutes were on our way— Mr Stone, the Editor of the New-York Commercial Advertiser had just time to deliver me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Colden, and depart— The boat is full of Passengers— Among whom are General Sumner of Boston, Mr and Mrs Girard with two infant children— Mr D’Wolf; a brother of the Senator from R. Island, Coll. Allston from South-Carolina, with a numerous family— Mr and Miss Coffin; and many others; all Strangers to me— The practice of drawing lots for births has been given up, and the first comers now take them— This was not known to me, and when the hour for the Night’s retirement came, all the births were engaged— One half the Gentlemen’s after Cabin was taken up for Ladies— A cot bed was made for me on the male side of the curtain, which answered my purpose sufficiently.

24. V:30. Quiet Night. On rising I found the boat nearly opposite to New-London— She went outside of Fisher’s Island, but the weather was so fine, and the Sea so smooth, that there was scarcely any balloting of the Boat, even where the movements are the most usually heavy— We turn’d point Judith, about 11. in the morning; landed Coll. Allston’s family and some other passengers at Newport soon after Noon, & reached the wharf at Providence, just at four P.M— Exactly twenty-four hours from New-York. There were several Carriages waiting on the wharf for Passengers— I engaged one of them to take us to Quincy. We travelled in Company with Genl. Sumner, Mr and Mrs Girard, and Mr and Miss Coffin— Saw on the wharf, Mr Eddy, the member of U.S. House of Representatives. A slight accident to our Carriage, just as we entered on the Massachusetts line at Pawtucket, detained us about half an hour; but we reached Fuller’s tavern at Walpole, 19 Miles, before nine in the Evening, and there stop for the Night.

25. V:30. Morning walk with George— We breakfasted at Walpole, and left Fuller’s about 8 O’Clock. At Dedham while the Carriages stopp’d I went to the Registry of Deeds, and took two Deeds which I had left there to be recorded in October 1819. We parted at Dedham from our fellow travellers who were going in to Boston— Missed our way, and went to Roxbury Street before turning off to Quincy. Just at one, we arrived at my father’s house; and I was deeply affected at meeting him— Within the two last years, since I had seen him, his eye-sight has grown dim; and his limbs stiff and feeble. He is bowed with age, and scarcely can walk across a room without assistance— After dinner Mr Isaac P. Davis came out from Boston with judge William Duer of Albany. In the Evening, Mr Quincy, now Mayor of Boston came out; but is obliged to return to Boston at four O’Clock to-morrow Morning. His occupations are incessant, and he has given a surprizing activity to the functions of his Office.

26. VI: I rode with my father, and my Son John to the Mount Wollaston beach and farm— Afterwards with my wife and my Son George, to Governor Eustis’s at Roxbury. But he was absent at Boston, and Mrs Eustis unwell; confined to her chamber. After returning to Quincy, I bathed with my Son John at the wharf. After dinner there were numerous visitors from Boston. Dr. Ingalls, Degrand, Clough, D’Wolf, son of the Rhode-Island Senator, King, and several others, personally unknown to me; and whose names escape me— T. Whitcomb and his daughter were also here. His wife died a few Months since; and he is himself much decayed in health and character— Degrand brought out some newspapers. There is to be chosen a member of the U.S. House of Representatives, for Norfolk District, in the place of W. Eustis, elected Governor of Massachusetts. A convention of Delegates, Republicans, from the several towns of the District, met last Evening, and agreed to nominate for Election, John Bailey, now in the Department of State. It was quite unexpected to me— I find myself here quite unable to write, and am under an irresistible propensity to idleness.

27. VI:30. Commencement day. My Son John was to have taken his degree this day— But he together with about forty others of his Class, were dismissed from the University last May, for disorderly conduct whereby they forfeited their degrees. I endeavoured to obtain a mitigation of this sentence by two Letters which I wrote to President Kirkland, but without success— I received here an invitation from him to attend the Commencement which I declined. My Sons George and John went to Boston. I rode with my father, and my Son Charles to Neponset Bridge—Thayer’s— Afternoon visits from Genl. H. A. S. Dearborn and Degrand— Genl. Dearborn brought out with him a manuscript in three Quarto Volumes. Walk with Degrand, over the Quincy hills— Evening visitors Captain Beale, and Mr J. Marston with his daughters— My wife’s brother Mr Thomas B. Johnson came out from Boston this Evening with my Son John.

28. VI.T. B. Johnson returned to Boston with John, who came back before dinner. Mr Whitney called. I enquired of him about the Church Records of his Parish, which was the first Church in Braintree— He sent me the first Volume of them, a small duodecimo Volume, commencing with the Settlement of Moses Fiske as Minister in 1671. From that time it contains in much confusion Entries of Baptisms until 1775, when a second Volume was commenced. A very few Entries of Marriages, and still fewer of Deaths— Some admissions to Communion— Dismissions to other Churches, and during a certain period, Confessions of fornication— None of these however, for the last seventy or eighty years. It is a meagre and chaotic Record; but it contains notices of births of my ancestors, both of the Adams and Quincy families, in which I take rather late in life an interest— They were both among the very first settlers of the Town of Braintree, and until now, I have known scarcely anything of them; not even their names— Received Visits from Mr Mrs and Miss Apthorp, and from George Beale— Bath with my Son John and ride, after dinner with my father to Bent’s Point Bridge— Mr John Wells, and his wife, and Degrand came out from Boston— W. S. Shaw came with my Son George— Visits from Governor Eustis, Lieutenant Governor Lincoln, and Mr Archer, Member of U.S. House of Representatives from Virginia. Eustis says he is perfectly satisfied, and has nothing more to desire on Earth; since he has been elected Governor of Massachusetts. He is much annoyed at the nomination of J. Bailey, as his Successor to Congress— Says it will make a schism in the Republican party— He is for Sever, who in the Caucus, consisting of 45 members had two votes. He invited me to dine with him next Monday.

29. VI.W. S. Shaw returned to Boston. We had numerous Visitors—Mr and Mrs Lloyd—Mr Hall the Sheriff and his wife, who was very ill while here—Mr and Mrs Sprague of Salem. John and Harriet Welsh—Miss Breck and Miss Hall—Edward and Mrs Miller— Two Young men, named Samuel Adams and—King came while we were at dinner— Adams is a graduate of Cambridge—of 1818. and a distant relation of our blood— Towards Evening I went out with my brother and my Son George to Savin Hill where the Independent Company, the New England Guards had been three days encamped— They honoured me with a salute. Met Degrand there, and came back with him to Quincy. Govr. and Mrs Eustis called this day.
I read in Manuscript the Correspondence between my father and William Cunningham which is about to be published— I do not remember ever to have seen a line of it before— Cunningham committed suicide on or about the 8th. of May last. Shot himself with a Pistol The publication is to be under the ostensible auspices of his Son.

30. V:15. Bath with John and Charles— George is suffering with the tooth ache; and went to Boston, where he had a tooth extracted. Visitors occupied all the Morning. W. Smith, brother of Mrs. Charles Miller— Chancellor (late) Kent of New-York, and his Son, Dr Nott, Mr Ticknor and Mr Dwight—Dr. Mrs and Miss Hill, W. Sturges, Dr Waterhouse, R. G. Amory, and Mr and Mrs. Webster— Mr Marston came to dinner; and W. S. Shaw— T. B. Johnson came from Boston, and I went with him and dined at Mr Quincy’s. Chancellor Kent and his party were there— This Gentleman has just been annuated out of the Office of Chancellor of the State of New-York, by attaining the age of sixty; after which the Constitution of that State, excludes every man from being a judge— The application of the Rule in this case is much regretted— We rambled over Mr Quincy’s farm; and saw his Salt-vats on the Beach which he has increased this year three fold— And his piggery; which however profitable is not cheering to the sight or to the scent— We had much pleasant Conversation at Table— Character of Lord Bacon’s Essays.

31. VI. Wrote to D. Brent, and made up a packet to send to the Department of State. Heard a Mr Randall preach—Morning from Luke 6.36. Be ye therefore merciful, as your father also is merciful. And afternoon from Proverbs 3.13. [“]Happy is the man that findeth wisdom, and the man that getteth Understanding” Both very sensible, and practical discourses— After Church, I bathed at the wharf and swam with my Sons John and Charles— There was a thunder shower approaching; and we had a sprinkling of the Rain— Captain Beale and his Granddaughter spent the Evening here.

Day. The distribution of my time this month has been necessarily various— The first twenty days of it like that of the preceding Months— Then a week of travelling, and the last week here at Quincy, in total relaxation and idleness.
